Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: We introduced a metallic nanograting at the bottom of thin-film tandem solar cells, and carried out an investigation into the light absorption in the top and bottom cells via the electromagnetic simulation. It indicates that broadband and polarization-insensitive light absorption enhancement can be obtained in the bottom cell, while the light absorption in the top cell remains unchanged by the influence of the added metallic nanograting. An overall carrier generation enhancement reaches as much as 60 % for both incident polarizations. This absorption enhancement can survive in a wide range of the cell thickness and the nanograting geometries, which enables us to reduce the thickness of the bottom cell with minimal impact on the light absorption. Thereby, this design could reduce the solar cell production cost, and meanwhile could enhance the solar cell efficiency by decreasing the light-generated carrier recombination rate.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Plasmonic solar cell is a type of thin-film solar cells which has the capability of trapping light in the thin absorbing layer by using the metallic nanostructures, resulting in an increase of the total light absorption [1–7]. Here, plasmons are thought to be useful because the absorbed energy is proportional to the electric field squared, and then the nature of their near-field enhancement causes a much enhanced absorption in a much smaller volume. Because of this, both localized surface plasmons (LSPs) excited by metallic nanoparticles and surface plasmon polaritons (SPPs) propagating at the metal/semiconductor interfaces are of great interests. Such plasmonic nanostructures can be added on top of, within, or at the bottom of the absorbing layer in a new solar cell designing.

Rectangular grating structure has been widely chosen in designing a plasmonic solar cell, due to its simple geometry and easy fabrication [1, 4, 5]. The grating structure applied in a solar cell was firstly reported by Atwater in 2007 [4–6]. By placing the grating on top of the cell, large light absorption enhancement was achieved in a narrow spectral range for the transverse magnetic (TM) waves, the case the SPPs can be resonantly excited. However, the absorption for transverse electric (TE) waves was suppressed, due to that the top metallic gratings acted as a reflection mirror for such TE waves [5]. Recently, our group proposed a new embedded structure in which the metallic nanograting was embedded at the bottom of the active layer[7]. This new design not only frees up those photons blocked by the nanostructures sit at the surface, but also achieved a broadband and polarization-insensitive light absorption enhancement. As much as 33 % of the light absorption enhancement when integrated over the full responsive solar spectrum was achieved in a 100 nm thick amorphous silicon (a-Si) thin-film solar cell.

In this paper, we placed an embedded metallic nanograting at the bottom of the absorbing layer in a tandem solar cell, composing multi-junctions of absorbing materials with different band gaps, such as a-Si and microcrystalline silicon (

Tandem solar cells were introduced to avoid a trade-off between the maximum absorption band and the maximum output voltage. In this research, we took the amorphous silicon (a-Si, with a band gap of 1.7 eV)/microcrystalline silicon (
$$\upmu $$
μ
c-Si, with a band gap of 1.1 eV) tandem solar cell as an example [9]. Up to now, most past researches have been devoted to reduce the top cell’s thickness, considering the unstability of a-Si caused by the light-induced degradation [10]. In this case, intermediate reflector layers with a lower refractive index, such as transparent conducting oxide indium tin oxide (ITO) or zinc oxide (ZnO), are usually introduced to trap short wavelength light in the thin top layer [10–13]. However, little attention has been paid to the naturally poor light absorption of silicon in the infrared band. To achieve sufficient absorption over those infrared wavelengths, the bottom cell has to be several micrometers thick, which will raise the production cost and then reduce the light-generated carrier collection efficiency due to the increasing recombination rate over a longer migration distance.

With the structure of a metallic (silver) nanograting at the bottom of the a-Si/
$$\upmu $$
μ
c-Si tandem solar cell, we investigated the light absorption of both top and bottom cell via the numerical calculation. Different from the effect of the surface-sit metallic grating, our technique gives rise to a broadband and polarization-insensitive absorption enhancement in the bottom cell, on the other hand the high absorption of the top cell remains unchanged. Over 40 % integrated light absorption enhancement and 60 % integrated carrier generation enhancement factor were achieved in the bottom cell. By varying the configuration parameters, it indicates that the light absorption enhancement can survive in a wide range of cell thickness and grating geometries. In addition, our study demonstrates that an Ag/Al bimetallic nanograting structure provides us with the same light absorption enhancement as that of Ag nanograting structure, but with a much less cost owing to the reducing Ag amount of usage.

The frequency-dependent dielectric constants of the four materials used in our study were interpolated from experimental data reported by ref [14, 15]. The computational domain was considered as a single unit cell surrounded by bilateral periodic boundaries and top and bottom perfect matching layers (PMLs)[16]. As shown in Fig. 4, we plotted the normalized and time-averaged electromagnetic field distributions at the peak absorption wavelengths previously shown in Fig. 2. The waveguide modes are clearly demonstrated in (a), (b), (c) and (d). For TM waves, the scattering from the silver grating caused a near-field enhancement at the silver–silicon interface, though it did not perfectly match the surface plasmon. In Fig. 5, we investigated the effect of the incident angle on the overall enhancement. As shown in the absorption spectrum (Fig. 2), the grating made less impact on the light absorption of the top cell (blue lines). For the bottom cell, the enhancement effect oscillated with the incident angle in tiny amplitude. An overall carrier generation enhancement of 60 % was achieved for both polarizations. Although the absolute absorption decreased at large incident angles due to the large reflection at the air/ITO interface, the absorption enhancement exhibited little dependence on the incident angle, and was even larger than normal incident case. It was ascribed to multiple effects participating in the enhancement mechanism.

Section1.Heading: Further discussion
Section1.Para:
To further reduce the cost of our new design, we consider the use of metal aluminum (Al) which is much cheaper than Ag. However, the enhancement is poor with the use of Al gratings only, because of the high intrinsic absorption of Al. Considering the fact that the electromagnetic field concentrated at the top surface of the grating and penetrated little into the grooves (Fig. 4), the substrate metal has little interaction with the incident waves and may have fewer impacts on the enhancement too. We proposed an Ag/Al bimetallic structure as shown in the inset in Fig. 7a). Compared to the Ag metallic nanograting, modeling results in Fig. 7 presented that this bimetallic structure was able to provide similar performances of light absorption enhancement, but with much lower cost.

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para:
In conclusion, we introduced a metallic nanograting to the bottom of the a-Si/
$$\upmu $$
μ
c-Si thin-film tandem solar cell. While maintaining a similar absorption in the top cell, the light absorption in the bottom cell was greatly enhanced in a wide spectrum. Three mechanisms, the Fabry-Perot resonance, planar waveguide mode and surface plasmon resonance, are involved in different wavelength regions. Overall carrier generation enhancement of 60 % was achieved. Due to the multiple effect included in, the enhancement exhibits little dependence on the incident angle and structural parameters. The Ag/Al bimetallic structure shows similar enhancing effects with much lower production cost.
